- The Minister can have no objection, because that is really what is meant.
- I ask leave to amend my proposed amendment in. the direction indicated by Senator Stewart, that is, by inserting the word " first " after the word " without."
- I have no objection.

speech.para: Amendment, by leave, amended accordingly.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

division.header.para: Question - That the motion, as amended, be agreed to - put. The Senate divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

quote.para: The cost of the survey authorized by this Act shall not exceed Twenty thousand pounds, and shall be charged on and paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is hereby appropriated accordingly.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the following words be added : - " Provided that no additional cost beyond the said £20,000 shall be incurred without first obtaining the authority of a special Act."

speech.para: I do not propose to debate this amendment, because in speaking to the proposal for the recommittal of the Bill I gave my reasons why I thought such an amendment desirable. I content myself with formally moving it, and I believe the Committee will be ready to accept it without further debate or delay.

talk.start.para: .- The amendment places me in a. very unpleasant position, and before I can vote for it I must ask the Minister of Defence a question. My principal objection to the whole scheme from the first moment I heard of it is the absolute injustice and unfairness of treating this railway as a Commonwealth matter.
- We have heard all that before.

- And the honorable senator will hear it again and again. Western Australia does not treat the matter in that light. She has admitted from the beginning that it was a State matter. She has offered to guarantee any loss on the working of the line for the first ten years, and has done many things to show that the principle implied in this Bill, that the railway is a Commonwealth matter, is not the true principle. I ask the Minister now whether he is prepared to accept a proviso that nothing in the Bill shall be taken to justify the assumption that this is a solely Commonwealth matter? If the Minister will not consent to that, will he, as being responsible for the Bill in the Senate, state that, so far as he is concerned and knows, it will not be taken to make it a Commonwealth matter? One honorable senator desired that this should be called an " Exploration " Bill, and it was pointed out that we had no right to explore two States. We know that it is a Bill chiefly intended to enable us to obtain information, to search the proposed route to see if a water supply can be found, to discover what it will cost, and whether it will pay to construct the proposed railway. Honorable senators have agreed to vote , £20,000 of the Commonwealth money for this purpose, but I have bean given no opportunity to submit an amendment under which the two States concerned would have to find the money, or to submit the proposal I made that the Commonwealth and the two States concerned should each bear a third of the cost. I admit that to some extent that would perhaps imply that if the railway were to be constructed the Commonwealth and the two States concerned should each bear a third of the cost of construction and of the loss on the first year's working. My difficulty is that this Bill can be pointed to for all time as evidence of the fact that in1906 the Commonwealth Parliament regarded this solely as a Commonwealth matter. Senator Playford should say whether he thinks that the Bill can be so regarded.
- I have been trying to ascertain in what way the honorable senator proposes to connect these remarks with the amendment.
- I feel great difficulty in voting for the amendment, because I want to learn how the Minister views the difficulties I have raised.
- The honorable senator has no right to discuss those difficulties on the amendment.

- I think I have. The amendment satisfies some honorable senators because it will bring the matter to an issue earlier than would otherwise have been the case. But it accentuates my difficulty, because it will provide that if £20,000is not enough for the purpose, the Government have only to ask for more money by means of a special Act, and it will be provided.
- If the amendment were not inserted the new Parliament would be able to do it in spite of honorable senators. Nothing Senator Dobson can do would bind the new Parliament.

- I object to put before the new Parliament this evidence that we have regarded this as a Commonwealth matter. To emphasize the Federal spirit, which seems to me to be so absent from honorable senators who represent Western Australia, I may say that I have from the first admitted that this is partly a Commonwealth matter, and I am perfectly willing that the Commonwealth should bear a fair share of the cost of construction.
- We are not dealing with the cost of construction. Why should the Commonwealth be committed to that?

- We are not dealing with it now, but we shall be dealing with it hereafter. Senator Symon knows the inception of this business quite as well or better than I do, and he is aware that this measure has its foundation in the fact that honorable senators from Western Australia will regard it as a breach of faith if the Commonwealth does not construct the proposed line.
- The honorable senator must see that his remarks are not relevant to the question.

- I have the greatest respect for your ruling, sir, and will not continue my remarks, especially as I shall have an opportunity to speak on the third reading of the Bill. Let me say one word more to the Minister of Defence. I still advise the honorable senator, as I did before, to tell the Prime Minister that if1s. is spent under this Bill, he and his Ministry will have their political honour tarnished.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

Senator Col. NEILD (New South Wales) [5.40]. - I object to the adoption of the clause in its present form, although I understand it is not competent for me now to move to amend it. I feel justified in saying a word or two in pursuance of the arguments advanced by Senator Dobson. In common with the honorable and learned senator, I submit that if this clause is passed in its present form, it will be an elaborate legislative indorsement of the contention of honorable senators from Western Australia, who have sought to propound and enforce a bargain for the building of this railroad by the Federal power. The proposition is too serious to be passed over so lightly, as there appears to be some disposition to do, perhaps because honorable senators have naturally exhausted themselves to some extent with the long debate to-day. In that debate I did not occupy more than three or four minutes, and I do not intend at this stage to speak at any length. I rise to indorse the serious attitude assumed by Senator Dobson, and to maintain the proposition which he has laid down, and which I also have endeavoured to enunciate.

talk.start.para: .- Do I understand that the Minister is not going to take any action in connexion with the amendment which Senator Millen desired to make?
- The Committee can only consider the matter referred to it.

speech.para: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with a further amendment.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent this Bill from being passed through its remaining stages without delay.

speech.para: A week ago it was an understood thing that we should divide upon this Bill to-day. I allowed it to go into Committee on the understanding that the third reading would be taken to-day.

talk.start.para: - - The Minister put forward as a justification for his motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders that there was an understanding that the Bill should be read a third time to-day.
- I told the Senate that I would move the suspension of the Standing Orders to-day.

- There was no such understanding. The compact was that the third reading should be set down for today, and honorable senators were to have an absolutely free hand to do what they pleased in the matter. That was the understanding, and there was no bargain or compact whatever that the third reading should be carried to-day. The Minister is quite within his rights in, moving the suspension of the Standing Orders for the purpose indicated, but honorable senators who object to the course proposed will also be quite within their rights in stating their objection. I object, and I intend to call for a division upon- the motion.

.- This is not a Bill that ought to be rushed through by suspending the Standing Orders, adopting the report, and agreeing to the third reading at one time. I wish to ask my honorable friend, Senator Playford, as a Minister sitting with his legal colleague at his elbow, whether he thinks it right to pass a Bill of this kind without such a clause in it as it certainly ought to contain? No one can tell whether any landowner who is injured bv the survey party will be able to obtain compensation. Either the provisions of the Property Acquisition Act ought to be incorporated with this Bill, or both the States of Western Australia and South Australia ought to insure that any person who' is injured shall be in a position to obtain redress. The omission Qf such a provision shows the folly of what we are doing. Will it be said that if the Commonwealth survey party injures any one, South Australia will pay the piper ?
- Are not these arguments against the Bill?

- They are objections to the suspension of the Standing Orders for the purpose of expediting the Bill. I protest against the suspension of the Standing Orders, and deny that any arrangement was made for taking the third reading to-day.
- I told the Senate to-day that I should move my contingent notice of motion with regard to the suspension of the Standing Orders.

. - I submit that it is not desirable to push this Bill to a conclusion to-night. The Senate is getting utterly tired of sitting from half-past 10 o'clock in the morning until 11 o'clock at night, and the procedure proposed by the Minister will make it more tired! I do not contemplate with any sort of pleasure being switched off from the Desert Railway proposal to the Excise Bill, but, at any rate, it would be a change. There is no real reason why the third reading of the Bill should be taken to-night.
- Honorable senators have all made up their minds, and there is no reason why we should not take the division, and get the Bill removed from the notice-paper.
- I point out that, even if the motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders is carried, it will not get the Bill off the notice-paper.
- But I shall ask my friends to sit all night, or until the Bill is passed. I frankly say that.
- Then it practically means that if the Standing Orders are suspended, we shall be kept here all night?
- Not necessarily - let us take a division !
- I do not think that that is a fair way of treating the Senate.
- If we do not dispose of the Bill to-night, the whole, of tomorrow will be wasted upon it.

- I do not think so by any means. If the third reading were taken in the ordinary course without suspending Bie Standing Orders, we should avoid an all night sitting. We could proceed this evening with whatever measure the Government chose to put before us, and could do good work upon it. But I am satisfied that we shall do bad work if we have to sit all night upon this Bill.
- The Minister himself is responsible for half the delay to-day.

- He is; and I urge him not to be responsible for any further delay to-night. If he makes us sit all night I say distinctly that he will largely imperil the chance of getting through such work for the rest of the session as he wants to do.
- There is too much threatening about the honorable senator. He is always threatening.

- I have not the idea of a threat in my mind. If I wanted to threaten, I could make my meaning quite plain. But I say that the inevitable result of an all-night sitting will, in mv opinion, be that the Government will have a difficulty in getting through work which many of us would like to see disposed of. Why not, therefore, take the third reading of the Bill to-morrow?
- If honorable senators opposite could talk all to-night upon the Bill they could talk all to-morrow upon it also.
- That is the sort of remark which the. Minister ought not to make. I have not the slightest intention of talking all to-night or all to-morrow upon the Bill.
- But the honorable senator cannot give an. assurance as to what other honorable senators will do.

- No one can do that. But I can point lo the fact that up to the present I have occupied very little time upon this measure. Although it has been before the Senate three times, the amount of time that I have occupied upon it is not great. I am prepared to give a promise so far as I am concerned.
- If the honorable senator can tell me that if the third reading is set down for to-morrow it will be disposed of before 1 o'clcok p.m., I will agree that it shall not be dealt with tonight.

- Much as I should like to say many things about the proposed railway. I will undertake that if the motion is set down for to-morrow I will not speak for more than twenty minutes upon it. I give that undertaking on my own account.
- If thirty-six senators spoke twenty minutes each it would represent a great deal of time.
- I have given a very fair promise, and I will go further and say that I will do my utmost' to enable the division to be taken by 1 o'clock to-morrow.
- But the honorable senator is powerless to carry it out. He cannot bind Senator Dobson, for instance.
- I think Senator Dobson will give, a similar undertaking on his own behalf.
- I want to have twenty minutes upon the Bill.
- Is not the Minister encouraged now?
- Why should we not have the debate to-night?
- Twenty minutes tomorrow or two hours to-night !

- If there is a general feeling amongst honorable senators in favour of taking the division before 1 o'clock to-morrow I shall be pleased to agree to what is suggested ; but will they help me to have the division taken by r o'clock to-morrow?
- Yes.
- Personally I cannot dc more than I have done.
- Will Senator Millen agree that the division 'shall be taken by 1 o'clock to-morrow?
- Certainly.
- What does Senator Givens say ?
- This matter ought not to be submitted to a kind of Dutch auction.
- I can assure Senator Playford that he will get on with business much better if he does not insist upon the Bill being read a third time to-night.

speech.para: Senator Sir JOSIAH SYMON (South Australia) [5.58]. - I think that my honorable friend the Minister of Defence might very well be content to have the report upon the Bill adopted at once, and the* third reading put down for to-morrow. He has obtained an assurance that those who have been most active in opposition to the Bill will assist the Government to come to a vote upon it by 1 o'clock to-morrow. Personally, if I have any influence, I shall exert it in the same direction. I shall be no party to sanctioning undue delay upon the measure. I accept the assurance that my honorable friends have given; and, further than that, so far as I am personally concerned, if I am not able to be present when the third reading is taken, I shall be paired. I make that an express stipulation. I think it is only a fair thing that on a Bill of this description, upon which, there has been so much debate from all sides, the wishes of the Senate should be considered.

talk.start.para: - Can the honorable senator get a pair?
- I shall bo here to-morrow until 1 o'clock.
- The opponents of the Bill may talk after 1 o'clock.
- Rather than that should happen I will myself give a pair to Senator Symon.
- I at once accept that assurance.
- Having said that his State would not agree to what is proposed, does Senator Symon think that he ought to vote upon the third reading of the Bill?
- I am going to vote for it.
- It is a very serious thing for him to do.
- I am very much obliged to my honorable friend for the solemn warning he has given to me..

speech.para: But I am quite prepared, the matter having reached the present stage, to vote for the third reading, especially as two years ago I myself introduced a similar Bill. I do not propose, the Bill having reached this stage, to go away before the third-reading division is taken on the understanding that every effort will be made to close the debate by 1 o'clock to-morrow. I at once accept the assurance of the Minister that every effort will be made to conclude at one o'clock. But I should very much prefer to have an opportunity of dealing with the Excise Tariff Bill to-night, if possible, and from that point of view, I am glad that he has taken a stand which I think will tend to expedite business.

talk.start.para: . - I desire to ask the Minister of Defence whether Senator Givens has given to him a promise not to keep us debating this Bill to-morrow ?
- If the honorable senator will wait patiently he will hear from me.

- As I understand that Senator Givens has not given a promise to that effect, I hope that the Minister will insist upon taking the third reading of the Bill to-night. We are quite willing to wait if some honorable senators should wish to speak for four or eight hours. Unless the Minister gets a promise of the kind T indicate I suggest that he should stick to his guns.
- If such threats are going to be made I shall withdraw my promise.

.- A short time ago the Minister of Defence asked me if I was prepared to promise that, so far as .1 am concerned, the Bill would be allowed to go through the Senate by 1 o'clock to-morrow. For two reasons I am not prepared to give a promise of the kind. In th'e first place if I desired to speak to the Bill I might be deprived of the opportunity to speak before that hour had arrived through the time having been taken up by honorable senators. In the second place, I refuse to give the promise to the Minister, because when I was speaking on a certain phase of the matter a night or two ago he very coolly told me that he took na notice of me. I take no notice of him now.
- No; I did not say that.

- I ask the Senate to accept my assurance that, in taking up an attitude of hostility to the suspension of the Standing Orders, my action is not directed specially against this Bill. All along I have strongly objected to any departure being taken from the ordinary beaten track. It was for that reason alone that I urged the Minister to follow the ordinary course. The Standing Orders should only be suspended when it is absolutely imperative. On the present occasion there is no emergency. Even if the session were to close at the end of the week there would be no necessity to suspend the Standing Orders in order to take the third reading of the Bill to-night. There is ample business to keep us occupied until even the late hour to which Senator Walker seems to desire to stay. We ought not to get into the loose habit of suspending the Standing Orders in this way.
- I only want to advance the Bill to the third-reading stage.
- The interjection shows that even the Minister recognises that it is not desirable to get into the general habit of suspending the Standing Orders.
- I have not done so in the case of any Bill this session.
- During the present session the Standing Orders have often been suspended, and I ask the honorable senator not to take that course now.
- I only want to get the report adopted to-night.
. - I do not wish to be placed in a false position to-morrow. There appears to have been a kind of undertaking given by Senator Clemons.
- Only for myself.

- If it were not repudiated now, it might be implied that honorable senators were in some way bound by the undertaking. Ordinarily, I would not assist to delay the proceedings of the Senate. If I were satisfied that a majority of the Senate desired to pass the Bill and that it would have their sympathy as well as their votes, I should be willing to let it go, but, not holding that opinion, I believe it is quite right to take any constitutional means possible to prevent its passage.

- I rise to a point of order. I submit that Senator Mulcahy has passed a reflection upon the votes of certain senators in saying that if the Bill were to be passed with their sympathy as well as their votes he would have no objection to offer to its passage. I object to the remark as a reflection upon the supporters of the Bill, and I ask for its withdrawal.

- Undoubtedly, according to a standing order, no honorable senator may reflect on a vote of the Senate. If Senator Mulcahy intended to assert that honorable senators have voted improperly that is, contrary to their convictions - undoubtedly it was a reflection upon their conduct. I do not think that he should make such a reflection.

- I am afraid, sir, that I cannot withdraw the expression of my opinion without being absolutely dishonest. I heard a representative of South Australia say that he would regard the construction of the railway as being absolutely disastrous to the best interests of his State, and yet he voted for it.
- The honorable senator is not discussing the question of suspending the Standing Orders.

- I am not bound by any promise which Senator Clemons may have given. I shall conceive it to be my duty to take every constitutional means I can to prevent the passing of the Bill - of course, without transgressing the rules of the Senate.

. - I have no desire to see the Bill passed through its final stage this evening. If I thought that there was to be no attempt at trickery, and to take a snatch vote, I should not care if the division were not taken this week, provided that it was taken before the end of the session. What has been the course of the debate so far? Has there been any attempt to get an honest vote of the Senate, or to get an honest pairing of absent senators who wished to vote in a certain direction? If, as I have said, there is to be no attempt at such trickery as taking advantage of honorable senators who may be absent, I am quite prepared to allow the final stage of the Bill to stand over to any day in this week, or, for that matter, in next week. But I want to have an understanding that there is to be no trickery - that the thing is to be done fairly and squarely.
- I do not think that the honorable senator should, by implication, accuse other honorable senators of trickery.

- I am not charging any one with trickery, but I want an honest understanding. I am expressing my conviction when I say that there has been every attempt made to prevent pairs from being given in order to prevent an honest reflex of the opinion of the Senate being given.
- I have already told the honorable senator that he ought not to imply that he is honest and the other senators are not honest. That is not a proper implication to be made.
- I recognise, sir, that a number of implications have been made which should not have been made.
- The honorable senator is not in order.
- I ask, sir, that the implication to which you have alluded should be withdrawn.
- Undoubtedly, the honorable senator ought to withdraw the implication that other honorable senators have acted dishonestly and with trickery.
- I desire to know what I am asked to withdraw?
- The honorable senator stated, so far as I could hear him, that other honorable senators had acted dishonestly and with trickery.
- No ; he did not say that.
- That is what I heard.
- What I said was that there was no honest attempt made to get an honest vote of the Senate, and that every effort was made to prevent pairs from being given.

- There is no obligation upon honorable senators to give pairs, therefore there is no dishonesty or trickery. Pairs are not recognised by the Senate. The honorable senator really ought to moderate his language.
- Perhaps Senator de Largie will allow me to say a word or two.
- You, sir, called upon Senator de Largie to withdraw an implication. Is the incident going to be passed over in this way?

- Perhaps I did not hear the honorable senator correctly. It has been stated by several honorable senators, by interjection, that he did not say what I thought he said. I understand from his explanation that he said that there was no honest attempt made to obtain an honest vote, and that honorable senators had been guilty of trickery. Is that what he said?

- What I said was that I do not care whether a vote be taken to-night or to-morrow, or any day next week, provided that when it is taken, an honest attempt is made to get an honest vote of the Senate, and that no trickery is practised in the matter of pairs, or anything of that kind.
- The honorable senator was only expressing a pious hope as to the future.

speech.para: Senator Col. NEILD (New South Wales) [6.14]. - I desire to make a suggestion for the consideration of the Minister. Undoubtedly there is a certain amount of tired feeling amongst honorable senators, and that I know from long experience often leads to some degree of hysteria in the small hours. I ask the Minister to consider whether, if the Bill is forced through the third-reading stage to-night, we may not run the risk of having something which will be described as " a scene in the Senate?" I hope that the Standing Orders will be suspended only for the purpose of adopting the report, which ought to be done without any debate, and that the third reading will be postponed until to-morrow, so that we can proceed with other business without any detriment to our tempers.

SenatorPLAYFORD (South Australia - Minister of Defence) [6.15]. - I do not think that there is the slightest fear of a scene arising. During its existence, such a thing has been practically unknown in the Senate.

talk.start.para: - If I could tell the Minister what I thought of him, there would be a scene here.
- No doubt if the honorable senator got nasty, and said unpleasant things, he might find himself sprawling upon the floor, and then there would be a scene, I suppose.
- We had a scene over this Bill two or three years ago.
- I wish the Minister to understand that, in view of what has been said, I withdraw from the arrangement I made just now.

- Then I suppose we shall have to go on. I am sorry, because I am quite willing to agree to what my honorable friends on the other side have suggested. I am quite willing to run the risk of the discussion being prolonged beyond even one o'clock, but if Senator Millen saysthat he withdraws, then, of course, we must go on all night.
- Does the Minister's reply debar other honorable senators from speaking?
- Yes, the Minister's reply finishes the debate.

- Would it not be better to divide the motion into two parts - that is, to suspend the Standing Orders so far as regards the adoption of the report, and then leave it open to the Minister to move the suspension of the Standing Orders in regard to the third reading? That would give a little time for consideration.
- What we are going to do-
- This is altogether irregular.
- This is very irregular, and we are only getting into confusion. I appeal to you, Mr. President, to say that we ought to obey the Standing Orders.
- By leave of the Senate, Senator Playford could amend his motion, but if no request to that effect is made, I must put the question.
- I must go on, Senator Millen having refused to abide by the understanding.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

division.para: Senator Col. NEILD (New South Wales) [6.20]. - There are many objections to the adoption of the report to-day. Full discussion is desirable in view of the question of public policy which is involved. We have heard a great deal about the monetary aspect of the Bill, but that, large as it is, is really the smallest. The State which I represent will have to contribute about one-third of the expenditure, and Victoria nearly one-third, the remainder being supplied by the other States. The "golden State" of which we have heard so much, is now the mendicant State, appealing for funds for a survey of its own territory. That is a melancholy position for a State which has been preening itself on having provided a livelihood for its poor relations in the east. We have been deluged and nauseated with statements about the large sums of money which Western Australian workers have sent to their poor friends in Victoria and elsewhere ; but now we find Western Australia appealing to the other States to pay for the proposed survey. I do not know whether it has reached the ears of every honorable senator, but it should be known, even at this late stage, that underlying the application for this survey, there are some very large mining interests - that this survey is to open up the country for boomster syndicates. I do not know whether that accounts for the inordinate anxiety to get this measure passed. Senator Walker was the first to suggest the mineral wealth of this howling desert - this place, where a wheelbarrow cannot be left out at night, because, before morning, it is lost in the drifting sand, and where a shovel, if allowed to lie, cannot be found at the end of five minutes. That is the actual experience related by gentlemen who had contracts for making dams which have never been filled with water, and which cost a good many of their namesakes. I remember Senator Walker saying that one of the objects this proposed survey would achieve would be the discovery of great mineral wealth. As that statement is by a gentleman of such a conservative disposition as Senator Walker, I can only suppose that he never devised the idea himself, but must have been, unconsciously perhaps, voicing what he has heard in the monetary world with which he is so closely connected. Had the matter rested there I should not have mentioned it, but we know what certain supporters of the measure in Western Australia are after. As soon as a survey peg is driven, and the surveyors move on, close at their heels will be the man, with the pick and the shovel and the dry-blower. There have been a great many dry-blowers here to-day on behalf of the railway, and I suppose we shall have a lot more before breakfast-time to-morrow morning. We are asked to take money out of the pockets of the people in the interests of a single State, and in the interests of mining speculators. As, for the South Australian people, they are of opinion that if a transcontinental line were built, their extensive docks, provided at an expenditure of £2,000,000 or £3,000,000, will be rendered useless, owing to the mail steamers' stopping at Fremantle - that interesting little hole in which a vessel cannot lie with any degree of safety, even at her moorings. There has actually been erected a paling fence to ward off the gales from the Indian Ocean, and when I first saw that fence, I wondered what sort of creepers it was proposed to grow over it. I was informed that it was intended, not to brighten the melancholy aspect of the beaten rocks, driven sand, and shallow waters', but to keep vessels from being blown from their moorings. I understand that a little time before that fence was erected a Yankee captain, on being asked to give a description of Fremantle, answered, ." It is a jetty in the Indian Ocean sheltered by the Cape of Good Hope." That is the interesting spot which the Western Australian Government wish to make the point of the arrival and departure of all our great lines of steamers.

talk.start.para: - I understand that the Minister of Defence is prepared to be content with the adoption of the report to-night, leaving the third reading of the Bill to be discussed tomorrow. If that be so. I am prepared to make good the offer in which I joined this afternoon to facilitate, rather than to delay, business. I have not occupied more than about a quarter of an hour in the discussion of the Bill, although I have felt somewhat aggrieved about an incident connected with it. I felt that I should, perhaps, be justified in displaying a little of the feeling I experienced, but I wish to do nothing of the kind. I recognise that the majority must have their way, however much I may regret that the majority was due to the incident to which I have alluded. Perhaps the Minister will say whether he is now prepared to be satisfied with the adoption of the report to-night, and take the third reading of the Bill to-morrow. If so, with a view to the speedy transaction of public business, I shall be prepared to abandon the speech I intended to make.
- I will agree to the suggestion made on the understanding that a pair is granted to Senator Symon.
- I understand that that has been promised.

- And on the understanding that the discussion on the third reading to-morrow will not be unduly prolonged, and that assistance will be given to enable the division to be taken before the dinner hour.

- There are many grounds on which I feel compelled to oppose the adoption of the report. One, as I have already indicated, is that the " Golden State " should come to us as the mendicant State, and ask for a survey of its own territory as though it were a boon to be granted to the taxpayers of the Commonwealth, to whom the people of Western Australia are never tired of referring as being less happily situated, with regard to this world's goods, than they are themselves. The Minister has admitted that the Bill is a nullity, because it provides only for the survey of a line, and the proposed survey will be useless unless two lines are surveyed. On the face of it. therefore, the Bill is not only a nullity and an absurdity, but it involves an actual misrepresentation, because it proposes that which is impossible. No man of sense would venture to say that a double line can be surveyed for something like 1.100 miles for £20,000. It would not be possible to carry out a flying survey for that amount. When the Bill was before us last session we were told that the country through which the proposed line is to run is a land flowing with milk and honey. We were told that a. flying survey was in progress, and that if we waited until the survey party returned we should learn what a land of Beulah this was ; that there would need to be a new John Bunyan, rather than a John Forrest, to describe its beauty. I fear that the only bunions connected with the matter will be on the feet of the unfortunate people who have to cross this country. The flying survey party went out and came back.

subdebate.1.para: They came back by the skin of their teeth if ever a set of unfortunates did. We are told that if it had not been for a lucky shower or two the explorers of this country would have left their bones to whiten in it. The foster father of the Bill, Senator Pearce, a few weeks ago produced some samples of grass grown in the territory. I thank God that I am not a cow, if it would be necessary that I should live on such grass. I should say that the only possible use to which it could be put would be to weave it in order to make rabbit-proof fencing.

talk.start.para: - It was starved cane grass.

- It was most melancholy looking stuff, and if it is a sample of the grass grown in the country, then God help the unfortunate people who will have to make this survey, and the horses they will take with them. We know that along a part of the line of route cement tanks have been constructed in the hope of conserving a little water, but so far they have never had a drop of water in them. The rainfall map of Australia shows that not more than five inches of rain per annum fails over this beautiful country. If we look at the reports of engineers, we will find that a sum of £70,000 was put down to soil " the sand-hills, as it is called, or, in other words, to cover the sand-hills which are a shifting quantity, so as to prevent the sand flying about and burying the wheelbarrows, and possibly the navvies engaged in the construction of the line. I .put it to any man of common sense to say whether it will be possible to maintain the integrity of a few inches of soil on the top of vast aggregations of sand dunes, if it is impossible to maintain the integrity of the- sand dunes themselves? The result will be that there will be flying dust instead of flying sand.
- This is far too funny.

- I have no doubt that the honorable senator is a very high authority on certain matters, but he is not a sufficiently high authority on the growth of vegetation to convince me or any man who has a knowledge of vegetation, that it would ever be possible, by putting a few inches' of dry soil on the top of vast aggregations of sand hills, to grow anything which would bind the surface together, and prevent the earth from being blown away as readily as the sand. Indeed, the earth would be blown away more quickly than the sand, because its particles are finer. The proposal to strew £70,000 worth of earth over the top of sand hills to prevent the burying of the line shows that the entire proposal is of the most haphazard character it is possible to conceive. I undertake to say that there is not a mile of railway in Australia in connexion with which provision has had to be made for the covering of the surface with soil. In this case, God knows where the soil is to be got. Those who recommended this course did not know and did not indicate it in their report. If I had known that I should be called upon to speak at length on this matter, I should have been prepared with interesting information on the subject. I went to Western Australia this year for the express purpose of gaining some knowledge. I took with me all the information available in the papers laid before both Houses of the Federal Parliament. I took a pile of Hansards, and that I retained my sanity in the circumstances says something for my intellect. I also obtained from the Department of Home Affairs copies of a number of documents which have not been laid before Parliament, but which I suppose will be, if they are asked for. When in Western Australia, I obtained copies of a number of interesting documents, and amongst others, a copy of the railway rates in force in that State, which shows how this rich country, which is now the mendicant State of the Commonwealth, treats the goods sent by the people of the eastern States to Western Australia. This is very pertinent to the question in hand, because what I have to say on the subject will apply to this line if it is ever constructed, and it will serve to show the kind of speculation and enterprise we are entering upon in this survey. One of the great arguments for the construction of the railway isi that it will serve to bring the products of the eastern and southern States into the mendicant State. Yet, if honorable senators look up the eloquent speech of the ex- Premier of Western Australia, Mr. Rason, they will find that he held forth in glowing terms on the fertility of Western Australia, and maintained that in a year or two the mendicant State would have all that she requires of her own production. By parity of reasoning, this line will not then be required.
- Western Australia exports wheat now.

- Very likely. But, meanwhile, while Western Australia is buying the products of the eastern and southern States, how does she treat them? Senator Styles mentioned this matter1 in a speech some time ago.
- Senator Playford did also.

- I did not hear him. Articles raised by the very States which are to pay for the survey of this line, are taxed from 50 to 170 and 190 per cent, higher than the products of the mendicant State itself are taxed in reference to railway transit charges.
- Thoroughly incorrect; the rates have all been revised.

- I happen to have so late a copy - and at the same time so early a copy - of the railway rates of Western Australia, that it was given to me before it had been passed through the press. It was a proof copy, revised with the pen before it had been finally printed.
- If the honorable senator had the latest copy, he would know that the rates for Inter-State produce are the same as for local stuff. The honorable senator's information must be ancient.
- Then the rates must have been revised in the interests of the present Bill. The date of my copy was May of the present year.
- Utterly incorrect.
- The honorable senator may say so if he likes, but the copy was given to me by the Premier of Western Australia, and I suppose that authority is good enough.
- I challenge the honorable senator to produce a Western Australian railway tariff which shows preferential rates against the goods of any other State. That is simply a question of fact.

- Clearly there has been a revision, but I am just as much entitled to have my word respected as Senator Pearce is. Evidently, if the rates have been revised, that has been done to assist the passage of this interesting little assault upon the rest of the taxpayers of Australia. That must be so, because it is a reversal of what has been the policy of Western Australia for I do not know how long.
- The present tariff is the consequence of an agreement arrived at by all the Railway Commissioners in conference.

- I may point this out, however - that no matter how, or where, or when, this line is constructed, the line designed to be eventually built as the result of the passing of this Bill can never do more than be a means of transit between two widely separated populations, lt will not produce a unity of settlement ; it will merely produce some facilities of communication. The settlement on this line will be no closer after the line is built than it is to-day ; because nature, in the form of a deficient rainfall, absolutely forbids settlement. There can be no artesian water of any consequence because there are no rivers. Over one-third of this continent - much more than a third indeed - and particularly in the portion that would be traversed by this line, the southern end of the continent, the rainfall for the whole year is only five inches ! Consequently, there can be no aggregation of artesian water; the rainfall is not sufficient to produce it. We cannot hope by putting down a set of sleepers and a couple of rails - it cannot be supposed that we are going to put down a double line - with watering stations established here and there at great cost, and at long distances apart, with the addition of a few residences for fettlers, and an occasional train running - we cannot hope, I say, bv such means', to bring about any Inter-State unity or to promote any bond of union between Western Australia and the rest of the Continent. Indeed, when I was in Western Australia last May, I met with a good many people of some local distinction, and I found that every second man one spoke to was talking about arming, and drilling to fight the Commonwealth, and break away from it. That was the common talk that I met with amongst the people to whom I was introduced.
- Was that why the honorable senator cleared out so quickly ?
- I cleared out just as soon as I had intended to do when I went there. I stayed ten days, but the climate was too "enthusiastic " for me.
- The honorable senator did not fear the armed resistance?
- Not at all. If Senator McGregor had been there, I might have done. I will not Sar why.
- Because he is a McGregor ?

- At any rate, his foot would not have been upon his native heath. It could only have been upon a sand-hill if he had been in the locality to be traversed by this line. All the eloquence that we have heard concerning the true Federal spirit and the bond of unity to be created by a row of white ant-eaten sleepers - all the talk to the effect that it is absolutely necessary to build this railway to save the Commonwealth from disintegration, is absolutely meaningless twaddle to any man with any kind of comprehension of the affairs of the world. I say without hesitation - I say it, if honorable senators like, prophetically, and I do it at the risk of having it proved in a few years' time whether I .am right or wrong - that the success, the growth, the development of Western Australia more closely threatens the unity of the Commonwealth than does the prospect of her remaining in her present mendicant position. And for this reason : that Nature has decreed so wide a barrier of desert between the inhabitable portions of the south and east, and the more or less scattered localities fit for human occupation in the west, that if the hardihood, the courage, and the strength of the people of Western Australia achieve so high a degree of development that they grow to become the great giant State that some of the enthusiastic occupants of that portion of Australia affirm will be the case, I say that Western Australia will become too great and too important to be satisfied to remain as an outpost of the rest of Australia. And she will never be more than an outpost, because, I affirm again, that the deficiency of rainfall prevents the. union of settlement between east and west. There will always be this terrible desert in which lives have been lost, and in which more lives will be lost ; and unless the greatest possible care and precautions are taken, this very Bill that is being dealt with so light-heartedly on the part of some honorable senators will be the warrant for the death of many of those employed in this wild country in connexion with the exploration of a route for a railway." This Bill should, I think, be recommitted for the purpose of altering its title. It may very fairly be described as the Western Australian Exploitation Bill.
- Who is going to exploit Western Australia?

- It is to be exploited for metals. We are told that that is one of the objects in view. We are assured that very great wealth underlies the shifting sands of the desert. I doubt whether great mineral wealth is there. If it is, so much the better. But a bare collection of mineral deposits very rarely causes permanent settlement. I grant that where you find great mineral wealth, as you find it at Kalgoorlie and one or two other places in Western Australia ; as you find it at Mount Morgan, in Queensland, and at Broken Hill, in New South Wales; just in the immediate vicinity of the mines you have a busy population who are engaged in the trade connected with winning treasures from the bowels of the earth. But whether that means permanent occupation and settlement I very much doubt. Let us take Ballarat as an example - I am not going to travel all over Australia for examples ; that one will suffice. I suppose there is no part of Australia in which the wealth of gold was greater than in the neighbourhood of Ballarat. But what is Ballarat as a mining centre to-day ? A very small affair as compared with what it is as an agricultural settlement. If you deprived Ballarat of its agricultural! surroundings to-day, its importance restricted to a mining field would not be considerable. Suppose we do find minerals along the line of route of the proposed railway? The survey party will- not be there to look for them. The " boodlers " will do that part of the business. They will come along and make all the discoveries possible. But there is nothing to warrant the idea that the discovery of mineral wealth will involve permanent occupation. What follows ? We shall be building a line to carry certain produce to the west which the west does not want, and will not buy; because the west says that she is rapidly providing for her own agricultural needs.
- From the sand?

- No; and the honorable senator knows that that is not a pertinent interjection. The idea of building a line for the purpose of creating friendship and unity between the east and the west is bunkum, because, I repeat, a row of sleepers- and a couple of rails would not accomplish that end. The reason advanced in favour of the proposal that the railway will bring the produce of the east to the markets of the west has been shown to be nonsense. Now I come to .another proposition - that the railway is desirable and necessary for purposes of defence. I would agree to that if we had any troops to send; but we have not. We have only to look at the officers' lists, published a month or so ago, to see how deplorably deficient many regiments are in that regard. I notice that one regiment which has an establishment of 26 officers is short of exactly 20. We know that for one reason or other certain difficulties have existed. Happily some of them have disappeared lately, and so far as I know there is a better feeling in the Defence Force than there was, and things are going on more pleasantly than they were wont to do. I am not ventilating any grievance or making any complaint. Granted that the ranks were full, and the regiments complete, the southern .and eastern States could not possibly spare troops to defend Western Australia,^ because we have not enough of them. We know how quickly a man-of-war moves nowadays. A cruiser can travel just as fast on the ocean as troops could travel over a railway with a gauge of 3 ft. 6 in. for a great proportion of the distance. If we had a fleet on the coast, say, off Adelaide, with troops on board, and they went into the offing, we could not follow them. We should not know where they had gone Could we strip Melbourne of troops to defend Western Australia on the off chance that in the darkness of the night or below (tie horizon the fleet had gone west when all the time they might have gone east? We could not strip Melbourne to defend Sydney or Sydney to defend A"delaide. or Melbourne to defend Perth. Under the present system each State must defend itself to the greatest possible extent. I admit that when we found that the attack really was made at Perth we could send, troops from here. But how long would it take the force to get there?
- What has all this to do with the Bill?

- I am answering a proposition that the construction of the railway is required for defence 'purposes. I am showing that first we have no troops to send over the railway, and secondly, that the distance is so great that given the start of the darkness of one night a hostile squadron could reach Western Australia from "the vicinity of either Melbourne or Adelaide as quickly by sea as our troops could do by this line. There would be delays from many causes. Trains would have to stop to take in water. We have not the express arrangements that they have in England, where an engine takes up water from a trough as she flies along. Certainly we could not have an arrangement of that kind in a desert. I do not want to elaborate my argument ; but I hold that for defence purposes the railway would be an absolute myth.
- That is the only ground on which the Minister of Defence introduced the Bill.

- I did not hear the Minister's speech, as I was away on some other public work; but if that is the case .1 shall feel justified in spending a little more time to elaborate the proposition. On his own showing, and on his own reports, the Minister is putting forward a fallacy, though no doubt in all good faith. I am sure that no one would for a moment suggest that in making a statement of that kind he was attempting to humbug the Senate. He is a man of too high repute and too honorable standing for us to suppose for a moment that he would deliberately try to delude the Senate, and the only explanation. I can offer is that he is singularly self-deluded. Any one who has paid attention to the subject of intraining and detraining troops, and the thousand and one difficulties that attend the rapid movement of troops, horses, guns, ammunition waggons, and the army medical corps' waggons or vans; any one who has had to show his proficiency in the subject, as is the case with a man who has held the positions I have occupied in the Defence Force, and is required to have all these matters at his fingers' ends, knows hat it would be impossible in an emergency to quickly mobilize troops, get them into trains, and send them off. There would be no use in sending away guns without horses. They could not all be put into one train. A succession of trains would be needed to carry even a brigade of 5,000 men. How long would it take to send 5,000 men with a few hundred horses, cannons, waggons, and supplies of rations for men and horses ?
- It could not be done.
- Certainly, with a single line, it could not be done in time to meet the landing of a hostile fleet, if they had the advantage of a night's start.
- We had evidence of that in the late Japanese-Russian war.

- Certainly. If the Minister of Defence really thinks that' a movement of that kind could be accomplished, and that the railway is necessary for defence purposes, I would suggest to him that, instead of those funny little staff rides, which are got up at times, he should try to send from Sydney to Melbourne with the proper equipment of guns, horses, and everything else, 500 men by train as against 500 men by a reasonably fleet steamer, and see which body would arrive here and be in fighting trim first. If he got as far as that he would find how utterly' the land project failed. I am arguing that the proposal that the railway would be useful for defence purposes is an absolute delusion, which honorable senators should not hug to their souls as representing any public usefulness. No doubt a railway would be a desirable thing to have. Just as I would buy a motor car for myself to-morrow, on one condition, and that is that I could afford it, so I would vote for the construction of this line to-morrow if I thought that Australia could afford it.
- This is a Bill, not for the construction of a railway, but for only a survey.

- I dare say that the honorable senator possesses what is generally described as an Englishman's castle, and that is his own home. Once upon a time he secured the services of an architect or builder and had plans prepared to meet his requirements. But he would not have spent his money if the plans had been suitable for, say, a rugged piece of ground which possessed only one site suitable for a house, unless he had secured the freehold or the leasehold or had an option which would enable him to become possessed of the land.
- The Bill provides that the Commonwealth cannot proceed with the survey until it has obtained the sanction of the Parliament of South Australia.

- We ought not to throw away £20,000 on a survey when we have not the remotest idea that it would ever be of the least value. If we are not allowed to build the railway, what is the use of having a survey made? Who would dream of spending money upon something which' he knew from the first would not eventuate ?
- The Commonwealth is asked to enter upon a project which it has not the right to complete.

- We have not the right to make even a survey, because we could be stopped at any time. I am told that the Government of South Australia have written a letter in which ' they have agreed to the making of a survey ; but that does not satisfy me. I have heard of such' a thing as a Ministerial change, and of a bargain which was made by one Government not being honoured by their successors. I believe that the Parliament of South Australia has rather a habit of changing its Ministry with a degree of celerity which indicates great political nimbleness, but not much political stability.
- There is a permanent Government there now.

- No doubt the Government will be very permanent until they are sent about their business. In Western Australia we find that the position is exactly the same. We are coming to a sort of understanding with a Ministry which has a faculty of jumping Jim Crow every few months. When I was there last May every one went to sleep one night feeling happy in the possession of a stable Government j but next morning he was electrified to .see an article in the press headed in large letters, " Resignation of the Prime Minister."
- In South Australia the Prime Minister is in the habit of going Home as Agent-General.

- In Western Australia the Prime Minister suffers from the same malady, because there are 1,500 golden reasons a year for not being cured of it. It is intolerable to me that such; a stupid thing should be proposed as to pass a measure affecting two States which are the most unstable of all in their political relations, and one of which deliberately declines to come to any understanding as to what is to follow if it should allow a survey of this line to be made. We are told that we must have two routes surveyed for the £20,000. I undertake to say that at least £10,000 would be expended in providing water for the survey parties. Indeed, I do not think the work could be carried out for £^10,000, because even for the smallest reservoir Portland cement is necessary, and in the country to be surveyed there is no stone available for such a purpose. I ask how it would be possible to convey hundreds of tons of Portland cement into this wilderness, together with hundreds of tons of water for mixing purposes? How would it be possible to construct cement reservoirs to be filled with water, which must be carried there on camels or pack horses ? I have clone a little concreting work myself, and I know that With two parts of cement, two parts of sand, and eight parts of stone a fair water-holding concrete may be made. But if it is not possible to get the eight parts bf stone, sand must be employed, and then, of course, it is necessary to have a much larger quantity of cement. We learn that the last exploring party were only saved by a thunderstorm from perishing with thirst ; indeed, I believe they underwent such terrible vicissitudes that they had to take their whisky neat ! I mention these facts to show that £10,000 would not 'be nearly enough to provide anything like an adequate water supply, if the survey is to be a bond fide one. I suppose that we are to some extent making history in working out a new Constitution, but certainly the conditions under which the Senate went into Committee on this Bill are so novel that I doubt if there is a single honorable senator who remembers a similar incident. I know that there is no analogous case in the records of the House of Commons. I do not desire to pass any strictures, but merely to point out that the Bill was recommitted under such restrictions that there was no opportunity to deal with it as many of us desired. The Senate is so evenly balanced on the question of this proposed railway that I am inclined to think that a majority might have been found for a recommittal on general grounds. Here I should like to draw attention to the fact that some honorable senators who are supporting the Bill have announced their intention to retire from political life, and it therefore would be serious if a measure of this kind were fastened on Australia by a majority including honorable senators. in such a position. Under the circumstances, we are entitled to debate the Bill in the fullest and freest manner.
- Does the honorable senator think that those who are about to retire have no conscience?

- I make no imputation ; I merely say that when a Chamber is so evenly divided, and the sense of responsibility on the part of those honorable senators is probably less than it would be under other circumstances-
- The honorable senator's remarks mean that some votes were given without conscience.

- The honorable senator has no right to place a meaning on mv words which they certainly do not con ve v. I am pointing out that the Senate is so evenly divided as to leave a difference of not more than one; and I feel such a sense of responsibility that, if the Bill be placed on the statute-book, I shall make it my business, at the earliest opportunity next session, to secure a repeal of the measure.
- Hear, hear !

- I am supported, by Senator Dobson, who, like myself, has not reached the end of his term as a senator. The very fact that Senator Dobson and myself should be united in a desire to repeal the measure emphasizes the vast difference between our position and the position of honorable senators who do not intend to return to the Senate. When a majority of one is arrived at under such extraordinary conditions, surely there ought to be the fullest debate and examination before we assent to the adoption of the report. Then there are involved large public issues, to which, so far as I know, attention has not yet been directed. We had a proposal in that aggregation of propositions and .promises which went to make up what was called the Vice-Regal address-
- Has the ViceRegal address anything to do with the question ?

- If you will kindly bear with me, sir, I shall show that I am clearly in order. I say that in that collection of propositions, submitted at the commencement of the session, was one for taking over the Northern Territory. That proposition is intimately connected with this Bill, from the point of view of broad public policy. It will be remembered that I desired last session to obtain the appointment of a Select Committee in connexion with this Bill. Owing to illness, I had no opportunity to explain what I desired in asking for that Committee.. I will say now in a few words that I had no wish that any time should be spent in the investigation of engineering questions connected with the proposal, not that a Committee of the Senate should attempt to accept the professional responsibility in reference to a huge engineering work.

subdebate.1.para: But I desired, and I still think it eminently desirable, that the Senate should have a proper appreciation of the large issues of public policy involved in our setting out to start a railway of our own from nowhere to nowhere.

talk.start.para: - Port Augusta is not nowhere.
- The honorable senator does not call Kalgoorlie " nowhere " ?
- From nowhere to nowhere as regards the Commonwealth, because the railway for which this survey is sought is to start from a town in one State, and to end up at a city in the mendicant State.
- Port Augusta on this side is connected with Sydney by rail.

- That does not matter. Senator Guthrie, with his intimate knowledge of maritime affairs, seems to regard the running of . a train inn the same way as the running of a steamer. I say that so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, the proposed railway is to start from no place over which as a Commonwealth we have or can exercise any jurisdiction, and to terminate at another place over which we have and can have no jurisdiction. I repeat that in the Vice-Regal address at the commencement of the session - that interesting collection of perdition paving stones, of good intentions sufficient lo pave, I do not know how much of that subterranean area we hear about - there was a proposal for the taking over of the Northern Territory. ' I have been to the Northern Territory, and it is about the finest place in Australia in which I have ever been - to come away from.
- What has the Northern Territory to do with the question?

- I think it has a very great deal to do with the question, because we cannot usefully 'take over the Northern Territory without making provision for some sort of connexion with it. and one of the conditions attached to the taking over of that Territory by the Commonwealth is the building of a line of railway by the Commonwealth up to Pine Creek.
- What has that to do with this Bill?

- The question at issue here is the construction of a railway across some other part of Australia, and I point out that there must be some limit to our railway expenditure. If by taking over the Northern Territory we are pledged to build a railway some 2,000 miles in length, how on earth are we to stand the double-banked extravagance of a line away to the west also? In my view we have to consider, not the passing of railway projects for the advantage of the mendicant State only, but for the whole of Australia. We are not sent here to build railways for one or two States. If 'railways are to be built by the Commonwealth, it is our duty to study the interests of all the States. When we have considered how much money it is possible for us to expend in this way, we must select the cross-country railway route which offers the greatest advantages to the greatest number. From that aspect of the question you, sir, will admit that I had a clear right to make the passing reference I have made to the connexion with the Northern Territory. But these are not the only lines proposed. We shall have Queensland insisting on her interests being considered in connexion with a line of railway which Premier Philp at the time of the establishment qf the Commonwealth, or some little time before, required not as a condition precedent to Queensland joining the Federation, but at least as one of the projects which the Federation would have to consider in the interests of his State, namely, a line terminating at the great estuary of the Victoria River, in the Northern Territory.

- Surely that has nothing to do with the Bill ? " I think the honorable senator is wandering from the question.. I have not stopped him, because, after all. this is only a motion for the adoption of the report, but the honorable senator, in speaking of the Victoria River, is certainly not speaking on this Bill.

- If it will help matters, I shall not say anything about the Victoria River. I am pointing out that we could not build every line of railway that might be asked for. Western Australia has put in a strong claim for this railway on the score of some implied desire if not promise. Queensland makes a less insistent application, but still some application, for a line of railway that will benefit her, and there is the third project, which will probably have to be looked into in the future, of a line running north through the centre of the

subdebate.1.para: Continent. We cannot build all these lines, but before agreeing to build any one of them we can examine them all, and see which will best serve the interests of the greatest number. That is the point I desired to make, and I had no intention to make a detailed reference to the other lines, their length, what they would cost, or the nature of the country through which they will pass. These are matters for investigation. We are, however, light-heartedly putting all our eggs into one little basket. How many lines of railway can we build if a demand is made for additional, lines? There is another point which must be considered in connexion with any project for railway construction. I am aware that this is not a proposal for the construction of a railway, but I say that we have no right to throw £20,000 away on this survey unless we follow it up by building the railway. If it is not intended to construct the line, we have no right to make the survey. We have no right to dip our hands into the taxpayers' pockets for is. to make this survey because of some sentimental idea, or in order to provide opportunities for mining " boodle."" We know that the Commonwealth Parliament has plainly set its face against public borrowing. How are we to build a line of this sort without borrowed money ? Some of the very senators who clamour for this line are men who have set themselves against public borrowing with faces of flint. I have made no secret of this. I pointed it out when in Perth last May. I said that Western Australia clamoured for railway communication with the eastern States, and yet sent men to the Federal Parliament pledged against public borrowing. In the circumstances, I told the people there that if they got no railway they would have to thank themselves for it to some extent. We are absolutely against public borrowing by the Commonwealth, while we talk of building this railway. No, we are dodging that. We say that we are only going to spend £20,000 on a survey. How much could be done with that money were it spent in some other direction? It might be a very small sum, but I was not aware that the Senate was so crowded with plutocrats that £20,000 is of no more moment to them than 2s. 6d. is to me. However, it looks like it when honorable senators can light-heartedly agree to spend £20,000 on the survey of a line which they know we have no authority to construct.

talk.start.para: - Sir John Forrest says, " What does it matter about a million or two ? "
- We are not all Sir John Forrests
- What purpose did the honorable senator hope to achieve last year, when, holding these views, he asked for a Committee to inquire into the subject?

- Unfortunately, Senator .0 'Keefe was not present when I explained that I had no idea of dealing with the engineering aspect of the matter, but proposed to investigate the questions of public policy involved in the selection of the best line of route by which to cross the Continent. In passing, I might say that my motion for the appointment of a Select Committee did not relate to this line only, but to any line which might prove to be most desirable in the interests of the Commonwealth. So far as the engineering aspect of the matter is concerned, I might add that I was for some years a member of the Public Works Committee in New South, Wales, and had an opportunity of making the fullest investigations into engineering projects for railways and other public works, and of examining and cross-examining official and unofficial engineers who came before the Committee to give evidence. I therefore have some little experience in dealing with such works, though certainly not with such wild cat propositions as "this.
- The honorable senator should say what he means by a " wild cat " proposition.

- I should say that it is very much of a wild cat proposition to spend £20,000 on the survey of the route ' of a 'railway 'which .we have no authority to construct, and no right to operate, and in view of the fact, also, that we have no right to occupy the starting or ending point of the line, which is to be on a gauge of 3 ft. 6 in. at one end, 4 ft. 8^ in. in the middle, .and God knows what at the other end. I say that it is a most haphazard, reckless, and careless project. It has not one element of statesmanship, commercial acumen, or even poor old commonsense to recommend it. I do not know that it is necessary for me to say any more in order to demonstrate the objection I have to the adoption of the report. I am not taking up time in the discussion of frivolous matter. At one point of the debate the President suggested that I was less in order than I ought to be, but I think that he will, not be disposed" to hold that view now, when he has heard Hie way in which I connect what I was saying with the motion. When one is subjected to a sharpshooting fire of interjections in the course of a speech, it is difficult to so connect one sentence with another as to display the continuity that is desirable. Of course, if this measure goes to its third reading, I may have a few other remarks to make. This leads me to a matter which I had forgotten. The proposed railway is to start from a point that is not under Commonwealth jurisdiction, and is to run to another point that is also not under our jurisdiction. Where are our railway works to be? Where are our railway authorities to be situated, and where are we to provide for all the paraphernalia in connexion with engineering, and so forth, that is required to manage 1,100 miles of railway? Are we to enter upon the functions of railway owners under some bargain, either with South Australia or Western Australia, for the repair of our engines and rolling-stock, or are we to have the line supplied with rolling-stock by one of the States? There are a thousand considerations of this kind which have never been discussed in the course of this debate. If they have been considered by the Government we have not heard of it. I sincerely doubt whether the Minister has ever considered them in view of the fact that Senator Playford's argument for the construction of the line was the mythical defence point of view, out of which I think the bottom has dropped. If the Minister of Defence would give us 50,000 troops instead of 21,000, we should have a force that would be able to be carried about. We have no such force at the present time.
- Is that all we have at present - 21,000 troops?
- A few more or less than that figure.
- -The Minister says that we have 60,000.

- But that includes members of rifle clubs. If mN honorable friend, Senator Clemons, will get the officers' list, it will open his eyes. He will find that there are regiments that ought to have twenty-six officers, but which have only six. Commanding officers are pitifully scarce. We even find a major acting as a State commandant. In Western Australia, for instance, the officer in command as brigadier has not even attained to the position of a regimental commander yet. I am aware that that is not my honorable . friend's fault. He is trying to put these matters right. A good many of them have been put right, and I congratulate Wm upon his success. I believe that if we had had him in office as Minister of Defence for a longer period, matters would not have been as bad as they have been.
- Is it in order for the honorable senator to discuss the number of officers we have in connexion with the Military Forces- in relation to this subject ?
- It was not in order, but I was replying to a question put to me by Senator Clemons.
- I was very glad to get the information.
- The honorable senator ought to have had that information himself. He might have obtained it from the published reports.

- If the Minister wilh in connexion with this Bill, promise me to raise the forces to 50,000 men, instead of their present low strength, I will support the measure. That is a proposition which I am sure is in order. If I could see any prospect under Ministerial promise of a force being provided, sufficiently numerous to warrant the hope of its being available for the defence of Western Australia, supposing this line were built, I should vote for the Bill. That is as absolutely fair a promise as a man could make. But I decline to give a vote for the passing of a Bill nominally for defence purposes, when I know just as well as I understand my own existence at the present moment, that the proposition is a sham and a fraud. I say with every respect, and with no desire to be offensive, that the whole idea is in the broad sense a public sham, because we have not the men to take to Western Australia in case of need. On that ground I cannot support the Bill. But I will willingly give the Minister my vote for the measure if he will promise us a force of 50,000 men. I will do more - I will undertake to raise 5,000 of them myself. I could promise to do that off my own bat, and know that I could fulfil the promise. But we have not a chance of having a sufficiently numerous force to make use of the line if it were built. Therefore, with the keenest desire to promote good feeling between State and State, and to discharge my duty as a representative of the people in connexion with this and other matters that are brought before us, I cannot see that I am justified from any stand-point whatever - beyond that of a vague sentiment - in giving a vote that means the taxation of my own State to the extent of between £6,000 and £7,000, and the taxation of Victoria almost to an equal amount, whereas the mendicant State would pay only a few hundreds of pounds out of the £20,000.

- I thank the honorable senator for the information. We find the six senators from Western Australia claiming an expenditure of £20,000, towards which' their State would contribute only £1,250, whereas my own State would contribute something like £8,000. I cannot light-heartedly join in this assault upon the pockets of the taxpayers of the rest of Australia in order that our mendicant brethren from the sand-patch may be able to have their State surveyed at our expense, without giving us any guarantee -that anything is to follow from the expenditure beyond the mere fact that a good deal of it would be distributed amongst their storekeepers, traders, and other folks who may be concerned in carrying out this very interesting proposition from a geographical stand-point, though it is a disastrous one from the stand-point of the public purse.

.- I desire to protest against the refusal of the Minister of Defence to allow the third reading to be taken at half-past 10 o'clock to-morrow morning instead of to-night. My honorable friend looks particularly unhappy just now. During the whole time this Bill has been before us, he has been unhappy. I admit that the Bill is enough to make him and his colleagues feel uncomfortable. I should like to know what steps they are going to take if the Bill is passed? My honorable friend, Senator Neild, touched upon a matter of which I have not heard much lately, because our friends from Western Australia have very tactfully dropped it. I refer to the good feeling which 'ought to exist between the citizens of the States of Australia. I should like to ask Senator Pearce and Senator Smith what kind of good feeling they expect from Tasmania if they. bv their majority - obtained in a manner which I will not attempt to describe - succeed m passing this Bill, and thereby obtain a contribution from my little State to help to establish their State's railway? Every other State of the Commonwealth has built its own railways. Look at the selfishness and unfairness of the whole proposal. Owing to the Federal Tariff, which does not produce nearly the amount of revenue that the Tasmanian Tariff formerly did, my State has absolutely lost £1.000,000. That is to say, the Federal Tariff has failed to take from our people that amount of money. It may be said that they still have the money in their pockets, but the Tasmanian Treasury has lost it, and has had to compel the people to make sacrifices in other directions. Tasmania has had to deprive the farmers of roads over which to carry their produce, she has had to deprive them of jetties from which to ship their apples and potatoes, and she has had to deprive the rest of our citizens of public works which were badly needed, but could not be provided because of the deficiency of revenue. But the State which asks us to build a railway for her, so far from losing a million of money, has had concessions made to her which were wrung from the Convention because Sir John Forrest told us that Western Australia would not come into the Federation if they were not granted. She has had a special Tariff for five years, under which, instead of losing a large amount of money, the Western Australian Treasury has reaped an advantage of as much as £800,000 or £900,000 in a year. And with these facts staring us in the face, the Western Australian senators calmly ask us to build 480 miles of railway in Western Australian territory and 6.25 miles in South Australia.
- Then South Australia will derive most of the benefit from the contemplated expenditure?

- Of course she will. Now, what are railways for generally ? The great idea in building them is that they conduce to land settlement, that they open up the country, that they are of enormous assistance to the farmers in getting their produce to market, that they develop the agricultural resources of a State, that they assist manufacturers, and that, in various ways, they help forward the prosperity of the country. For years the farmers of Tasmania had to cultivate their soil and market their produce without the assistance of railways, because they could not be afforded. At times they had to market their produce by means of roads which were unsuitable for even a bullock team to use.
